The Cabinet resumed the discussion ofGovernment Policy at the Indian Round Table Confer-ence.In this connection they had before them a most secret Memorandum by the Secretary of State forIndia (C.P.-285 (31)) on the subject of the North-West Frontier Province Constitution.The Cabinet were informed that the work of theIndian Round-Table Conference had taken longer thananticipated and that the Conference would not, as previously expected, terminate during the week beginning November 22nd, but during the following week beginning November 29th. In these circum-stances the Prime Minister did not submit to theCabinet at this Meeting the statement he intendedto deliver at the close of the Conference.The Cabinet then discussed once more, In thelight of the various ctirrents of opinion in theIndian Round-Table Conference and of the Parliament-ary situation in this country, the question of which of the following courses was better:-(i) While adhering to an All-IndiaFederation as the aim of HisMajesty's Government, to intro-duce "during the present Sessionof Parliament a provincial autonomy Bill:(ii) To postpone/provincial autonomyuntil the full scheme of anAll-India Federation and provincial autonomy could becompleted involving a delay of eighteen months or two years:(ait) To invite the Indian Round-table conference to express an opinon as to whether (i) or (ii) was. preferred.After the above question had been discussed and decisions taken (see, below) the Prime Minista?gave the Cabinet an account of an interview which he and the Lord President of the Council had had, late on the previous evening, with a deputation fromthe Conservative Party's India Committee.After a comprehensive discussion of the wholequestion the Cabinet agreed (a) To approve generally the policy whichhad been adopted at the Cabinet Meet-ing referred to in the margin:(b) That, in his statement at the termin-ation of the Indian Round-table conference, the Prime Minister should,inter alia, repeat the substance ofthe declaration he had made at the endof the First Session of the Round-table conference on January 19, 1931, as tothe intentions of the Government(Cmd.3772, pp.80-83). He should also make clear that.as an earnest of their good faith, His Majesty's government intend to introduce legislationproviding for provincial automonyduring the present Session of Parlia-ment, and that the work necessary tocomplete an All-India Federal Consti-tution will be i*w^^**^e4 at. once bythe despatch of appropriate committees to India. He should refer to thennrmTvmaJ.. qjigja&jon on the lines of"Conclusion ( c) below) - He should include a statement as to theConstitution of the Worth-west frontier Province as a Governor'sProvince (See Conclusion (d) below) .He should "also inform the conference that both Houses of Parliament willbe asked immediately to endorse his statement.(c) The Prime Minister should make clearthat. His Majesty * s Government in theUnited Kingdom could not allow theProvincial Autonomy Bill to be upsetby the absence of a Communal settlement in India. If the various sections inIndia had not been able to reach agree-ment among themselves by a date early.in' the New Year to be specified,the Governmentwould themselves have to take certaindecisions as the basis of their Bill,and in doing so they would adhere as closely as possible to the status quo.The position, however, would be left in such form that if agreement were reached subsequently in India areadjustment could be made. (d) That the following formula, proposedby the Secretary of State for indian CP,-285 (31), should be used asthe basis of the passage in thePrime Minister's declaration relatingto the North-West Frontier Province:-"The North-West Frontier Provinceshould be constituted a Governor'sProvince, of the same status as other Governors' Provinces, due regard being had to the necessaryrequirements of the Frontier, Itis intended, of course, that in theNorth-West Frontier Province, as indeed in all other Governors'Provinces, the powers entrusted tothe Governor to safeguard the safety and tranquility of the Provinceshall be real and effective."(e) That, in order to ensure the carryingout of the proposed procedure, thefollowing arrangements should be made:-(i) The Lord Chancellor should endeavour to expedite thework of the Conference sothat the next Plenary Sessioncan be held on Saturday,November 28th, and the finalPlenary Meeting on the morning of Tuesday, December 1st:(ii) That the Secretary of State forIndia should arrange that thePrime Minister"s statement should be printed and availablefor distribution in the Parlia-mentary Vote Office ... early inthe afternoon of Tuesday,December 1st, that is to say,shortly after the statementhas been made at the close ofthe Conference.(iii) That the Parliamentary Debatesshould take place on Wednesday,December 2nd, in both Houses^(f) That the text of the Prime ministers statement at the close: of the conference should be considered by the Cabinet attheir Meeting on Wednesday next,November 25th. (The question whetherthe text should be circulated inadvance or not was left to the decisionof the Prime Minister.) The President of the Board of Trade informed the Cabinet that he had received a very importantDeputation from the Coalowners of this country onthe subject of the imposition of fresh Import Dutiesby Prance which operated with special severityagainst the coal trade of this country. The cabinet were informed that the increase amounted to 15 percent., or 3/- per ton on British coal. It had been imposed without any notice whatsoever, althoughBritish representatives had been in conference withthe French Government on these questions on theprevious day. The new Duties operated with muchgreater severity on British than on Belgian and dutch coal, and the effect was to exempt our Polishrivals altogether.The Prime Minister invited theSecretary of State for ForeignAffairs tQ take up the question with the President of the Boardof Trade. mpE DISARMAMENT 4.
